speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: Chapter Nine: Preparing Clone Audio. The quality of your clone is a direct reflection of the quality of your reference audio. A perfect clone comes from a perfect sample.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: The most important requirement is silence. Your reference audio must contain only one voice, with no background music, no reverb, no crowd noise, and no other speakers. Even a small amount of background sound will bleed into the clone.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: The ideal length is between three and ten seconds. Less than three seconds does not give the model enough acoustic data to work with. More than fifteen seconds does not improve results and can sometimes introduce instability.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: The speaker should be using a neutral, conversational tone. Highly emotional performances — shouting, crying, or whispering — are harder to clone cleanly and produce a voice that is more difficult to direct once cloned.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: You can record your own reference audio directly in the app using the Transcript Helper tab. It can also crop an existing audio file down to a perfect sample, and its built-in Whisper transcription will generate an accurate text transcript for you automatically.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: A great practical workflow: use the Transcript Helper to record yourself reading five to eight seconds of plain text, trim the clip, click Audio to Text, and then hit 'Send All to Voice Clone Tab'. Everything transfers over in one step.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: Please load Chapter Ten: The Lock Voice Feature, and we will cover the single most important time-saving tool for voice cloning sessions.
